If you're looking for VR for the PC games you have on the xbox gamepass app, this won't do it. For that, you'll need to install Steam, get the free SteamVR app,  launch it, then approve it in your oculus, then launch your PC game.

This is basically just your xbox console games streamed to a virtual 2D screen. The resolution and screen size aren't terribly great, and the oculus controllers will not work with your games (you'll need an xbox controller and  dongle/receiver for your PC). It works, but IMHO, the standard virtual desktop is better.

Honestly I enjoyed my experience with it, but with a a few minor upgrades like allowing the gyroscope to work as a thumb stick on an Xbox controller and allowing to screen to be full size i would rate it 5 stars

This app is awesome. The console GPU takes the weight of the game so your PC's GPU only needs to play the video stream. So in effect you have two GPUs working together. The VR image is rock solid and the graphics quality on the screen is much better than what you get with Big Screen and similar apps. You can play movies on your XBOX, or Youtube, and stream to the Rift as well. If you are lucky enough to have both a Rift and an XBOX One in your house then get this app! Thanks XBOX for a great free app.

As the app explained, this allows you to play your xbox one on the Oculus Rift. You're in an environment that allows you to adjust the curvature, distance, and size of the screen. You have 3 different environments to choose from. Microsoft has also allowed us to adjust the volume of the environment, if you want to immerse yourself in the game sound only. I highly recommend it. My personal favorite was the Dome, as it was somewhat dark, allowing me to focus on the gameplay. I tested the streaming on medium, while playing Halo... almost felt like I was MasterChief himself, as I adjusted the screen to cover nearly the entire Rift screen with curvature. (As most of us know that Halo is a FPS with the view being from Chief's helmet.) This game requires a good stable internet connection for the best experience, otherwise you'll have stutters and lag as well. Most reviews I've read so far are giving the app below 4 stars, but honestly... there should be no reason that anyone would review this anything below 4 stars. Most games recommend a GTX 970 or Radeon 290, I recommend nothing less than an RX 480 or GTX 1060 for any VR game to enjoy a smoother experience on all apps.

My only recommendation would be to include a Void environment, as a few others recommended as well in their reviews. This is something I'm sure plenty of people would be on board with.

Does exactly what it says it does. Streams the 2D display of your Xbox One to a screen inside a virtual enviroment in your Oculus.

If you think it does more than that you need to read the description again.

Basically this app is good to use if you can't access your TV for gaming because other people are using it, or if you want to experience Xbox One on a larger screen than you own. If neither of those matter, the standard eyestrain caused by the Oculus makes this app not really worth using.

The distance, vertical position, and curvature of the screen can be adjusted, nothing else. Dome was my preferred enviroment simply because of how open it is and I was able to position my screen so that it filled almost the entire Oculus display, combined with the curvature this can simulate VR gameplay with an FPS... as long as you don't actually turn your head.

I didn't encounter any Install issues, but it does freeze the install if you remove the headset, just like Oculus freezes all it's games when the headset comes off. Though it does continue to stream when the headset is removed once things are up and running.

I took the headset off and let it idle for about 45 minutes after it was running and when I came back it would only give me a black screen. I had to close and restart the app, a common issue with streaming technologies when they idle out.

My network is all hardwired and capable of 100 MB/s (averaging around 10-20MB/s). I experienced no lag or latency issues with the display or controller during my test play (I played Overwatch for 10-20 minutes) and was even streaming an HD movie through my network with Vudu for my son while I was playing.

I had slight blurring during fast in game movements, which is also typical of streaming gameplay. Aside from that nothing was visually wrong aside from the standard eyestrain you get playing anything in VR.

All in all.. It's exactly as advertised.

Somehow this streams without the network issues I get with the Windows 10 app.  Maybe the lower res helps, I don't know, in any case it's a nice free app that lets you play Xbox One on a virtual big screen.  I don't mind the resolution issues, I wouldn't use this for serious long play sessions anyways.
I can hear my Xbox one playing, but have not been able to get  a video signal. I've tried this with two different games. I can stream to my Windows 10 PC just fine, but the Oculus only gets audio...

Since I've set up my 2 sensors in the opposite corners of my room, even after reconfiguring the sensors multiple times, xbox thinks my center view is to the left. It also thinks I'm sitting inside the floor. It desperately needs an option to re-center the display without being able to see the icons (Since they are beneath the floor)

review_title: Why? BigScreen does SO much better.
one_reviews_text:
There are only 3 environments. Of those, 2 are fundamentally flawed for this purpose because the screen sits above me and can't be curved enough or in the right direction. The one environment that's decent, has a freakin hand-rail in my view. Ironically, that environment is the only 1 of the 3 where I could find the controls and because I chanced on them there, I realized that if I basically lay on the floor in the other 2, I could find them.

The virtual screen control is seriously lacking and flawed. It's above me in 3 of the environments (contrained by the environment floor) and cannot be curved in the vertial or enough in the horizonal. You also have no size control (convergence), only distance and limited height.

Move the virtual camera (users position) up in all 3 environments, allow more curve in the horizontal, add distance/convergence, and some curve on the vertical, then cause the controls to come up (occulding the environment, if not closer to the user) when the user looks down, and this could be usable.

In the meantime, BigScreen is free, multi-player and even they most simple [lack of] environment; the void, is more usable. Why would I bother with this?

MS, I happen to know a UX designer you previously employed, how could have done FAR better and could fix this up in a hurry if you'd like a referral. Of course, I'd be happy to help too :)

Also, if you like to watch movies from blu-ray, it's no-go since Xbox one blu-ray player does not support streaming, that is last dot to the end.
